content_scrubbed:
I kind of did the inverse of that.

I did my undergrad at a well-known private university (AMS Group I).  A[.] & B[.] in my math classes the first two years without really trying.  Then my junior year I took real analysis, thinking I could do the same thing.  I never really learned my lesson, and finished the last two years as a C student in most of my classes.

After graduation and a failed attempt at getting a job as an actuary, I worked in retail for a few years before finally deciding to go back to grad school.  With my weak grades, weak recommendations, and weak GRE subject test score, I was only admitted to an AMS Group III school, the flagship public university in a pretty small western state.

However, the environment in grad school was perfect for me.  It was a relatively small department, and I felt like I "fit in" much more than I did as an undergrad.  I was more mature (started grad school at 25) and learned how to study.  I did great in all my classes and developed good relationships with the faculty.

And most importantly, I had a teaching assistantship the entire time.  It was a small department, but the university had a big engineering school.  So it needed *tons* of instructors for the calculus/diff eq/linear algebra courses.  I got some wonderful teaching experience and consistently won the department[.] grad student teaching award at the end of the year.

With the teaching experience, I was a relatively attractive candidate for more teaching-oriented positions after I got my PhD.  My interviews were pretty much all for positions at small private liberal_arts colleges or regional campuses of larger public universities.  A couple non-tenure track positions at bigger places.

I ended up with a 2-year visiting position at one liberal_arts college, and moved to a permanent position at another after that.

I love it.  The teaching load is big, but I still get to do some research.

I guess the moral of my story is that if your undergraduate experience wasn't the greatest, then it[.] still possible to get a PhD and have a career as an academic mathematician.  However, I would *not* recommend my path to someone who wants to end up at a top-rank school doing lots and lots of research.
